segments.text: I received far more attention from the press than I ever wanted.
I'd say 50% of it was accurate and 50% of it was exploitation so I could sell the damn article.
Really?
Yeah.
You thought the exploitation was that high?
I thought the exploitation was extremely high, particularly with some individuals.
Who were the worst ones?
I guess the worst one was a communist reporter, Nicholas Tomlinson, from the London Sunday Times, who was killed in the Israeli conflict in 60-73, October War 73.
He got what he deserved.
He, I guess, was the worst because he got a full page on me on the London Sunday Times and every paper here in the United States and he wrote from fright, total fabrication.
Yeah, I was looking for a story that Americans were killing civilians.
So he rode with me one afternoon in the helicopter and we got in a few firefights.

Not at my request, but Westmoreland sent him down to Depew and Depew bucked him off to me and I had him in the back end of the helicopter when I was doing my duty that day and I'd forgotten that he was there.
Wouldn't have made any difference anyway.
I'd go ahead and do what I had to do.
And he wrote the article.
I mean, a full page on the London Sunday Times.
Zap, zap, general killing civilians and so forth.
And the general said he'd rather do it.
Wasn't anything he'd rather do better than to go kill the Kong and all that kind of crap, which was all fabricated, all lies.
He got what he was coming from, Israelis.
He got killed over in the Israeli conflict.
Did you ever write to the, was it in the London Times you said?
Yeah, it was the London Times, but it was on the front page of every newspaper in Houston and everyone in San Francisco and Los Angeles and every damn place all over the world.
Did you overwrite and refute it?
No, hell no.
You don't bother with that crap because they're not going to print it anyway, you see.
The Chief of Staff of the Army said I'd set back the Army's public relations by three years or something going forth.
And my answer to that was, well, General,
must not been a very doing a very good job if you're gonna let a communist-inspired bastard lie like hell and I'd say the Army's in pretty bad shape.
What'd he say?
He didn't say anything.
I never heard from him.
Did you did the Chief, did you write the Chief of Staff?
No, I didn't write anybody.
I just didn't pay any damn attention.
I didn't know about it for maybe a month later.
Oh really?
Oh yeah.
And then the Air Force
agents picked up an article by a Navy, a Soviet Navy lieutenant wrote a book, children's book for the Soviet children, elementary school.
Wrote a nice little thin book about a lesson that had three-eighths of an inch thick.
Had pictures of ducks and little girls picking flowers on the front of the book and the inside of the book
The Story of the Number One Cannibal in the Vietnamese War.
And it was from this Tomlinson's article that the Navy lieutenant had wrote this book for the children of the Soviet Union.
OSS got a copy of it.
You know, they got copies, I got a copy of it, the Air Force sent me a copy, the Special Agents of the Air Force.
I sent it to my mother, and I guess she didn't know what it was, and threw it away, and I've never been able to get a handle on another copy of that.
Miss Hollingsworth searched children's libraries in the Soviet Union to try to find it, but it just so happened that that had been removed everywhere she went.
I had a bad taste in my mouth about that.
Tell me about some of the other press people that you dealt with.
Marty Safer.
He was all right.
Hart from, I believe he was CBS.
I think he was NBC.
NBC.
Yeah, he was NBC.
God, I can't remember any more of them.
They were all right.
They didn't hurt me.
Did they try to do an accurate job?
Did the American press in general try to do an accurate job?
I thought the American press did a fair job.
I thought they did a fair job.
The best guys were guys with real common sense and sound judgment and already had made enough money that they could eat, you know.
And that makes a difference.
Such as?
Joe Alsop, he was the best.
Walter Cronkite, old Walter would get bad information and fed to him and he just read off every evening what somebody else had fed him to say.
And sometimes he'd say good things, sometimes he'd say bad things.
But did you meet him?
I knew Walter, I guess I met him.
Did he come over to Vietnam when you were there?
I don't know whether I met him at a press club in Washington or whether it was over there.
I can't remember now.
He's an awful good man.
I was trying to think of some of the guys from Wall Street, but I can't think of their names now.
BBC was never very helpful.
British Broadcasting Company.
I think we got pretty bad press from all of the Europeans.
Well, I'll tell you, you asked a question I haven't answered yet, and that is, should they be over there?
And the answer is absolutely not.
Who should give the news to the American people?
Let it come from an ambassador from the area who's doing the operating, the civilian side of it.
In other words, it should have been handled more like this recent Falkland crisis.
One hundred percent.
Now there, it was a group of professionals down there allowed to run the war.
You see?
And what's the end result?
You win.
Get her over with.
You know, every time that happens or the Israelis do something like that, it just makes us look like a bunch of damn fools over here.
I'm talking about our bureaucratic, administrative, governmental,
uh, everybody in the damned act, uh, when he's, uh, everybody's sticking his finger in the damn pie.
And we somehow or another, we gotta get a hold of ourselves and quit looking like fools to the rest of the world and quit trying to go buy, uh, friendship.
We don't want any friends.
We want people to respect us.
that's what we want.
And we don't want to go buy it either with money or try to do it because we should have learned a lesson by now, don't you think?
After multi, multi, multi-billion dollars worth of taxpayers' money trying to buy friendship when what we really ought to have was demanding that people do things right and them respecting us for it.
that's what it's all about respect now in the world today and I still travel throughout the world really and truly no one respects the United States isn't that a terrible thing I want to ask you
A couple last questions about Vietnam, then we're going to move on.
A lot of people blame a lot of people for losing that war.
Why do you think that we lost, obviously, because the military wasn't allowed to fight the war?
Who do you blame?
Congress of the United States of America, who represents all the people.
Congress of the United States.
who represents all the people.
And I've talked to many of them and they agree with me that that's what it's all about.
I've had the most sincere of them and the older ones tell me, General, we'll never do it again.
Well, I'm not so sure.
Hell, they'll all be gone in another 20 years, so what the hell are you up against the next time?
And what the hell do the Congress of the United States or the Army
or administration of the American people ever remember from one conflict to the other.
Nothing.
That brings me to the last question I want to ask.
What did we learn from Vietnam?
What did the Army learn from Vietnam?
We relearned what we knew from Korea, and in Korea we relearned what we knew from World War II.
and I guess that the next conflict we'll get in we'll probably relearn what we forgot in Vietnam.
And what's that?
And that is that discipline and training
and availability of weapons and ammunition and high standards of performance during peacetime and wartime bring success.
And that people are important and don't push them beyond their capabilities and the leadership has to thoroughly and clearly be trained
in such a manner that they can understand the capabilities of man.
That's the way I see it.
When you returned from Vietnam, President Nixon gave you your third star.
Is that right?
My third star came in July of 73, and I can't remember who was president then.
I don't know.
He was.
I think he still was.
He did exactly what he told General Haig to pass on to me that he was going to do.
How did you feel about that?
You mean about the president?
About the third star.
Well, I felt, just as I'd said to General Abrams, I've got only one eye left and I don't know whether I can see well enough to do what needs to be done to command 250,000 men or not.
But my eye got a little better after a little rest.
I got it pretty well patched back together.
He sent me down to Fort Sam Houston.
I had a deputy commander down there until I could give me a chance to, I had to rest up.
And then you went off to Korea.
Yeah, I went to Korea.
Korea was your last major assignment from July of 73 to February of 76.
That was the last command assignment.
I had another assignment after that.
Yeah, but that was your last major assignment.
Yeah, major assignment.
What did you see as the problems there when you arrived?
What was your mission?
Bad strategy, bad defense concept, bad policies by the United States for 23 years since 1953.
Poor support for the American Union, poor support for the Koreans
I walked into the United States Army Ammunition Depot and I found some, in this one area, some 3,000 8-inch artillery rounds and only 100 fuses.
When I got through looking at the whole ammunition in support of that front, I short 156,000 fuses for 155.
millimeter artillery and eight-inch artillery.
What'd you do?
I tore the damn place apart.
And I found Honest John Rockets with corroded fins.
I found the Honest John Rocket Battalion with 20 rounds of rockets that everybody said was ready to go and the corrosion had eaten up the fins.
And they were totally unserviceable.
But that was no different.
That was bad, but that wasn't the worst thing.
The worst thing was a mission for the

American Eighth Army of and the Koreans and the assistance of the Koreans of defending the Republic of Korea and the capital city of Seoul which consists of eight million Koreans located 25 miles from the DMZ and their policy
And their concept for descending the capital city of Seoul in the Republic of Korea was to fall back on successive lines.
And the last line was buttressed up against the capital city of Seoul, and I merely asked the question, how do you defend the capital city of Seoul
if your last offensive position is on the northern outskirts of it.
I said, have you gentlemen here ever heard of attacks by fire?
Have you ever heard the communist theory that if you can physically defend the capital city of Seoul from us,
We'll disallow it to you because we'll destroy it by fire.
So, with the great support of President Park Chung-hee, not so much U.S., I bulldozed through

which approved by the Secretary of Defense and the DMZ up there, I bulldozed through a new offensive training program, a new offensive concept for the defense of the Republic of Korea and 37 million people.
Be damned the American policy, the ambassador, and even General Stilwell, my commander, has
helpful as he wanted to be, he also had to look at the State Department political side of things.
But before I left there, for the first time since MacArthur went to Yellow, there was a plan that had been exercised in the field attacking to the north.
And I did that.
I guess a lot of people take credit for it now, but I tell you what, I fought day and night to get that done single-handedly against the United States.
Why was the United States against this?
They had a policy of falling back because they were afraid the Koreans might attack the North Communists.
So their policy was, don't give them anything.
disallow them, they actually disallowed them over the years prior to my presence there, disallowed them the facts of life on the real capabilities of the Communist North.
So they were afraid the South Koreans would get an offensive plan and attack the North and get the United States in a war.
That's State Department crap.
And you cannot lie to a sovereign government.
I don't care who they are.
And I would not put up with that at all.
I told the Koreans the truth.
I broke the green door down from a standpoint of them having information that they ought to know.
about the strength of the North.
You see, our policy was don't tell them anything and they won't ask us for any more arms.
We would say, oh, you've got enough.
You don't need no more.
The enemy's only got this amount.
You don't need no more.
In their fear, if you give them too much, they'll go attack the North.
Well, what did Henry Kissinger, the Secretary of State, have to say about your policy?
When the May collapse came in 73, no, I guess it was a little later on, was it 74, when the Vietnamese took Saigon, I mean the Communists took Saigon,
Must have been May of 74, yeah.
May of 74.
No, it was early in 75.
Or was it 75?
Yeah, 75.
It was May of 75.
May of 75, okay.
Yeah, let's see.
72 is when we fought.
Yeah, it took them three years to get their goddamn offensive capability back together.
That's
That's how badly we beat hell out of them in 72.
Their offensive capability we destroyed.
It took them three years to put it back together.
That's right.
That's right.
May of 75.
President of Korea said, Are you going to let down...
South Korea as you did Vietnam.
That's what he asked you?
Yep.
He asked our government this.
He asked our authorities this.
He asked ambassadors this.
He asked me personally this.
I had a personal relationship with him, which the United States didn't like worth a damn.
Why not?
He was the president, and I was the only field army commander, and they had an ambassador there, and they had a four-star general there, and you know how it goes.
But they had nothing they could do about it.
Nothing anybody could do about it.
But he said, what are you going to do?
Are you going to let us down, same thing?
So we had What did you respond?
I said, no.
I said, no.
I said, we had no mutual security pact validated by the Congress with the Vietnamese.
He said, but your Congress, your president has, you're going to treat us like you did Taiwan.
You had a mutual security pact with Taiwan.
That's a good point.
I said, Mr. President,
I came over here and I said, I'd fight and die with your units out here to defend this country.
And that's what I intend to do.
And I said, I worked to change the strategy in which you supported me.
And I said, by God, we've got ammunition in here.
We've got the air power so we know we can get it in here.
And I said, I just want you to know that I am totally convinced that we will live up to our treaty in the case of Korea.
Well, of course, this word went back to Washington by our ambassadors on the 4th, so what we really created was an assurance program to reassure Korea that we would do it.
Ford got in the act and said, by God, we'll bomb the hell out of the bastards.
Kissinger said, we'll bomb the hell out of the bastards.
Schlesinger, in defense, said, we'll bomb the hell out of the bastards that come down there.
And, of course, my whole strategy, in which everybody was against, which is now in being, fell right into the hands of saying, God damn it,
We're not giving up anything.
I said, Mr. President, we're not going to give up one inch of your precious land.
He picked up on that and started telling the Korean people.
And every governor of every province I visited, I made speeches to them.
In every province, I visited industry.
I was known by all of them.
The new strategy of taking the offensive should the enemy attempt to cross the DMZ and killing them with firepower, the introduction of B-52s,
Introduction of F-111s over there bombing on the ground so everybody could see them.
The introduction of fighter-bomber demonstrations right near the DMZ.
The coordination, teach them how to consolidate artillery fire and time on target.
I fired 33 battalions over there one time to show them.
And the little Korean soldiers got up out of their holes and clapped and sang because they knew
For the first time, by God, we're not going to be run out of these positions.
Somebody said, why didn't you fire 33 battalions?
I said, well, I had to do one better than I did in World War II some 25 years ago when I laid 32 battalions on 22 Tiger Royals.
And I said, that's exactly the reason.
And of course, nobody in the American Army has ever seen anything like that before.

unheard of but i did it in korea you lined them all up and just let it go no you move them in you don't line them up you move them in they're sitting everywhere but they're sitting many four and five miles apart in depth and all back over 33 battalions and you just blow the whistle tot time on target
You hear guns way back to the rear, boom, boom, boom, boom, boom, boom, and then ones up front finally shooting and every round hitting at the same time.
It's the most awesome sight that you can see.
It's equivalent to about a 10 KT warhead in conventional firepower.
And this is a demonstration to the South Korean people and to their military what I'm talking about about winning.
They left no doubts in their mind.
So that brought on in 12 months time forward defense which has been accepted.
Everybody talks about forward defense.
Forward defense is
Destroying the offensive capability as quick as, or the enemy's capability as quickly as possible.
Destroying his attack as quickly as possible and then attacking yourself.
Again, with a high volume of fire.
Don't go bring over ten American divisions.
You don't need any damn American divisions.
You got more, all the American divisions you need over an hour at one.
And that's for present purposes.
that you're there and that you're going to stay and you're going to fight and die with them.
What you do bring over is firepower delivery stuff, air power, B-52, F-111.
Now, right after you left and That's where I won the money, Mr. Quintus.
As a result of that, in 12 months' time, all the thousands and thousands of acres of fallow land

behind the DMZ was opened up and the president believed so much in what I was doing that he put the Department of Agriculture, Korean Department of Agriculture and irrigation people up there and started irrigating all this land in 12 months.
They had received, for the first time in 4,000 years, it had become self-sufficient in rice grain.
In addition to that,
We started a reforestation program.
They burned all the trees to stay warm because they had no clothing during the war, and the enemy did likewise.
And so it's time now to reforest, get forests growing like they used to be with pine going forth in the mountains and all over the place.
And each of my three Lieutenant General Corps commanders took on a responsibility of pulling necessary soldiers out in his Corps area of responsibility.
And over the course of the last two years of the era, they planted 15 or 20 million pine seedlings, of which
They got from 80 to 90% growth rate in each of the different core areas.
Fantastic.
The president built new roads for me.
The governor came to me and he said, sir, I want to honor you with this gift here, he said, governor of the province.
He said, the president down yesterday, I've been trying for five years to get a new road up to Tan Du Shan, from Wu John Bu to Tan Du Shan for the second infantry division, U.S. infantry division.
And said, the president came down yesterday and made a speech about you and said that I had asked for a road and that he was going to get it.
And they built it.
Dedicated it.
Then he turned to me and he said,
any other roads you want, go on into it.
And I said, yes sir, one out here connecting my first corps and my fifth corps.
And he turned to the minister of construction and that was built in my honor and finished a few months after I left.
No kidding.
Yeah.
And uh,

It was a very heartwarming thing for me to fight my own country and the interests of my own country and the interests of those 37 million people over there and get something done that was right and proper.
At first, the State Department, you said, was against your policy, but then after 1970 My concept was strategy.
and after 1975 and the fall of Saigon, then they turned around and they accepted your policy and it fit right in.
Is that correct?
Yes, exactly right.
And then they got off your backs.
They got off my back then, yes.
It was kind of anxious for me to leave because they weren't so damn sure that I wouldn't
I think they felt that I might entice the Koreans into attacking to the north.
Really?
Oh, yeah.
I mean, you can't imagine what goes through the minds of some of the cheap people we got in this country in high places.
Honest to God.
For example You mean you got the word back from the State Department?
No, I did not get that back from the State Department.
I got that from members of the
of the American staff in Korea.
I got word also that one of my corps commanders and I, the first tunnel we found over there, that there's some question about whether or not that had been dug at my insistence.
Tunnel for what?

tunnel from the north at the communist north that dug under the DMZ so they could get slip into South Korea we found this tunnel and then we found another much larger one and some of the midget staff people of both the state and the army
were mouthing around that General Hollingsworth and the Corps commander had instigated the tunnel on their own.
Oh, you can't imagine what you have to go through as a public servant.
Did you formally have to respond?
Hell, no.
I tell them to go to hell.
I said, well, you ignorant bastards.
I mean, someone called and asked you?
Oh, no, what they do, they pass it to your staff.
They don't bother you.
They're afraid to talk to you, you see.
They're afraid to talk to me.
But they staff the staff and say, well, there's been discuss down here as to whether or not this is a fake thing and that your boss and the corps commander didn't dig this tunnel on their own.
Jeez.
You've got some cheap people in this country.
You've got some ruthless people.
Who do you think originated this?
Oh, somebody that didn't want this tunnel to happen.
Who do you think came up with this rumor?
Oh, hell.
Who's responsible?
I don't know.
I tell you what, you never pay any attention to this sort of thing.
Then they didn't want anybody to come up and see it.
The U.S. didn't.
Because they still didn't want to believe it.
But the Koreans sent people up there to see them anyway.
So after the U.S. looked like a bunch of goddamn fools for a while, well, then they say, all right, I guess we can let a few people go up
see it.
Who's they?
The ambassador?
State department officials and high military officials in Korea.
Who was the senior military officer in Korea?
Let's see, I think General Stilwell was at the time, but that doesn't necessarily say General Stilwell did it.
Maybe he had some
major general staff down there.
You never did know whether Stilwell really meant that or some underling did that, you see.
Because Stilwell was a damn sharp, common sense sort of fella.
But he also got some pressures from the ambassador.
The ambassador's the number one guy over there, you know.
and so you never know what kind of pressures he gets from the ambassador.
He has to respond to him.
Let's talk a little bit about, we've already talked about how you got along with the president of Korea.
Tell me about the relations that you had with the people of Korea.
You said you visited factories.
Did you go out and
sort of campaign for your strategy, or what?
No, they invited me.
You see, my headquarters was 80%, I believe, 60%, can't remember the percentage now, somewhere between 60% and 80% Korean.
My deputy was a major general, Korean.
My chief of operations was a brigadier general, Korean.
My chief of intelligence was an American colonel.
My chief of staff was an American brigadier general.
The deputy chief of staff was a Korean colonel.
So, on a key position, my chief of supply and logistics was American with a Korean deputy.
Korean in a key slot, the deputy was American.
Wherever the American was a key slot, the deputy was a Korean.
So, I was the commander of the field army, and the deputy was a major general Korean.
So, they know what the hell is going on, and they keep all the Koreans advised, you see.
And so, most all this business of

my visiting amongst the people and going forth was my interest in the people and their industry, which had to participate in supporting what I needed from the standpoint of logistics support and supply and material for the twelve Korean divisions that I commanded.
I only had one American division, but the other twelve were
were Korean, so it was all Korean.
And the 2nd Infantry Division, my American division, wasn't going to fight anyway until I started attacking to the north.
Now I was going to let them, I had a plan to let them attack to the north as a matter of honor for the United States.
You know, you can't have the United States Army over there fighting a war and them just sitting on their ass.
What did you think of the capability of the Korean forces?
One Korean division properly equipped can stand off three Soviet divisions and two American divisions.
They're the toughest little guys that you've ever seen in your life.
We used 4,000 rounds of artillery in training each year for our artillery battalion.
They'd been forced to by necessity and to conserve ammunition because they never knew whether the United States was gonna, until I was there, until the United States was gonna run out on them or not.
So they were very conservative about their ammunition.
But they trained so well and would fire 300 to 600 rounds of artillery per battalion of 18 pieces and they'd out-shoot the U.S.
In the U.S., it would shoot 4,000 rounds a year or more of training.
That's how good they are.
They've got some, and I prefaced my remarks earlier by having them properly equipped.
They need more secure voice communications.
They don't have that.
They need some air defense weapons.
for their divisions.
They need new and better artillery ammunition.
They need better tank ammunition.
But as far as physical fitness, alertness, readiness, leadership amongst themselves, they're tops.
After your return in 1977, President Carter
was thinking about bringing some American troops home from Korea.
What was yourhe didn't do itwhat was your opinion?
There was a lot of resistance from the military.
What was your opinion?
My opinion was that the United States had announced that
They have a national interest in the Western Pacific, Japan, Australia, the Malacca Straits, for trade and for friendship and for many other reasons we have national interest in the Western Pacific.
And they always come back and say in key places, Japan.
The defense of the Republic of Korea is vital to the defense of Japan, absolutely vital to the defense of Japan.
Korea and the peninsula is a very dangerous land.
Surrounded by communist Chinese, Soviet communists, and a totalitarian communist state of North
Korea supported by China and the Soviet Union.
So it's a very dangerous peninsula.
And our presence there plays a major role in maintaining stability in Northeast Asia.
And why play in the hands of the Communists by pulling Americans out of there and then taking a chance on the
Chinese communists, South Korean communists overwhelming the South Korean government and then becoming a major threat to Japan and Australia and the Malarca Straits along with the Soviet fleet.
Does that make any goddamn sense to anybody?
Only to a guy named Abramowitz who was ambassador to Thailand who was the instigator of
trying to withdraw my headquarters and the Americans for a long, long time.
He sat over in the Defense Department and he played footsie with those coming in in the Carter administration and this is one of the things that he perpetuated.
He got himself an ambassadorship out of it.
I testified along with him and General Vesey in the Senate Armed Services against the withdrawal.
That gentleman right there, Senator Sam Nunn, and his knowledge of what's needed to be done over there, was a key instrumental guy in defeating the whole damn thing and keeping them over there.
And there isn't any questions about that.
This Bromowitz went on to be the ambassador.
